div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The New York Times, April 27, 1924 [Enclosed in KAFI0010]
div1.p: THE NEW YORK TIMES. SUNDAY, APRIL 27, 1924.

Credit to the One for a Great Medical Discovery and
to the Other for a Great Feat
of Sanitation

p.hi: To the Editor of The New York Times:

div1.p:
In June, 1902, President Charles W.
Eliot of Harvard University gave to
Major Walter Reed the honorary degree
of M. A. with the citation, “he gave to
man control over that dreadful plague,
yellow fever.” This is the inscription
on Reed's tombstone in Arlington Ceme-
tery and its truth has not been chal-
lenged until now. Therefore the friends
of Reed and Gorgas and persons inter-
ested in the history of medicine have
been surprised recently to see what was
the crowning accomplishment of Reed's
life, the demonstration that the stego-
myia mosquito was the infecting agent
of yellow fever and the only one
claimed for another and that other
Gorgas.

In a very clever and entertaining
article in a current magazine, “Yellow
Fever Meets its Master,” by Marie
Doughty Gorgas and Burton J. Hen-
drick, occurs the statement, “Even when
Reed had completed his work Gorgas's
position was still one of extreme caution.
That the stegomyia mosquito could
transmit the disease was unassailably
proved; but was this the only way in
which it could be conveyed? Was it
even the ordinary way? That, Gorgas
held, had not been demonstrated. * * *
In the next few months, however, it was
clearly to be shown that the stegomyia
and the stegomyia only, was the infect-
ing agent, and the man who was to
make this clear for all time was Gorgas
himself.”

This statement arrived at its conclu-
sion by ignoring the admirable and con-
vincing series of experiments of Reed
with infected bedding and clothing and
with the discharges from patients,
which made it as clear as the noonday
that the stegomyia was the ordinary
and the only normal way of transmit-
ting the disease. If these experiments
did not convince Gorgas, neither could
conviction be drawn from his own ex-
perience in the next few months, for he
continued, until the middle of August,
1901, the disinfection of bedding and
clothing of yellow fever cases, which
Reed had shown to be unnecessary.

This claim is introductory to a state-
ment in the beginning of the fourth
chapter which is equally erroneous. It
is that Reed's demonstration was a
mere academic performance which Reed
himself saw no practical way of apply-
ing. The intimation clearly is that the
methods of warfare against the mos-
quito were unknown until devised and
put into operation by Gorgas about
Feb. 15, 1901. This is, however, far
from being the fact, The writings of the
distinguished entomologist, L. O. How-
ard, had made the use of kerosene to
control mosquito breeding well known
to army sanitarians. Under the stimu-
lation of Reed's influence the chief
surgeon of the Department of Western
Cuba had, on Oct. 15, 1900, three
months before the acceptance by Gor-
gas of the mosquito theory, published a
circular to medical officers calling at-
tention to the fact that mosquitos were
known to convey malaria and filarial
disease and were suspected of conveying
yellow fever also, and directing the pre-
vention of mosquito breeding by the use
of kerosene on deposits of water. On
Dec. 21, 1900, still before the conver-
sion of Gorgas, General Order No. 6
was issued from General Leonard
Wood's headquarters directing, with
minuteness of detail, the warfare
against mosquitos. As Gorgas began to
put in practice two months later the
procedures specified in this order, it
cannot be claimed that he was the dis-
coverer of anything not already known.

The general order above mentioned
was published in Harvard's "Military
Hygiene," second editon, William Wood
& Co. What he, Gorgas, did do is well
stated in a letter he wrote to Reed,
dated Aug. 20, 1901, in which he says
"I am very happy to shine in the more
humble role of being the first to put
your discovery to extensive practical ap-
plication."

The fame of Gorgas is secure in the
performance of the greatest feat of san-
itary administration that the world has
seen. It does not need augmentation by
claiming for him what belongs to his
brilliant and unrewarded friend, Walter
Reed.

J.R. KEAN,
Colonel, Medical Corps, U.S. Army
Corps Area Surgeon
Washington April 17, 1924.
